awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Investigation of Ningaloo Nino: The role of Madden-Julian Oscillation and Leeuwin current variability
awd_abstract_narration:
During the strong La Niña event in 2010-2011, extreme ocean warming and a marine heat wave off the west coast of Australia were observed. This extreme warming event is termed as "Ningaloo Niño", an analogy to other eastern continental boundary warming phenomena such as El Niño in the Pacific and the Benguela Niño in the Atlantic. During the recent Ningaloo Niño event, SSTs off the west coast of Australia were more than 5 degree centigrade above long-term seasonal means, which is sufficient to impact large-scale atmospheric circulation and has devastating impacts on marine ecosystems and resources. In this region, locally and remotely forced ocean circulations in the southeast Indian Ocean, such as Leeuwin current system, may play a crucial role in the development of the Ningaloo Niño event. The primary goal of this proposed project is to understand physical processes that control the development of Ningaloo Niño/Niña. The proposed project will contribute to the plan and design of major international field campaigns and improving observational network in the Indian Ocean, enhancing education through supporting students and a post-doc, and advancing climate prediction. One of the PIs' institutions is recognized as a Hispanic Serving Institution by the U.S. Department of Education, and thus the project will contribute to providing training opportunities for underrepresented minorities. In addition, the proposed research will identify key processes that must be represented well in climate models, which will help improve climate model simulation and benefit society by providing more reliable climate prediction. 

A variety of oceanic processes that affect the 'Ningaloo Niño' will be explored in the proposed study including: 1) The impact of the remote forcing from the Pacific Ocean versus forcing over the Indian Ocean on the Leeuwin current system and Ningaloo Niño/Niña;  2) Effects of topographic trapping of westward radiating Rossby waves and their associated downwelling/upwelling associated with Ningaloo Niño/Niña events; 3) The influence of the MJO on Leeuwin current and Ningaloo Niño/Niña via oceanic processes; 4) The role of Australian summer monsoon in affecting the Ningaloo Niño/Niña events. A high-resolution Indo-Pacific basin ocean general circulation model (OGCM) will be employed, which can adequately represent complex bathymetry and topography in the Indonesian Seas. The data from enhanced in-situ observations and satellite data will be thoroughly analyzed and maximally utilized to validate the model. A series of process-oriented OGCM experiments will be performed, to quantify the impacts of remote & local forcing on the Leeuwin current system and Ningaloo/Niño, and identify key processes involved, including the role of coastal Kelvin waves and radiation of Rossby waves. The results will identify the physical processes that determine the sea surface temperature and upper-ocean variability associated with Ningaloo Niño, which can alter atmospheric circulations. In particular, the impacts of Madden-Julian oscillation and the remote forcing from the Pacific on the Leeuwin current system and Ningaloo Niño, which cannot be isolated by observations alone, will be quantified by a series of OGCM experiments. Consequently, completion of the proposed project will substantially advance our understanding of the dynamics of Leeuwin current system and Ningaloo Niño that is major climate variability in the southeast Indian Ocean.

Brief Summary of the outcomes

During the strong La Niña event in 2010-2011, extreme ocean warming and a marine heat wave off the west coast of Australia were observed. This extreme warming event is termed as "Ningaloo Niño". During major Ningaloo Niño events, SSTs off the west coast of Australia were more than 3-5C above long-term seasonal means, which is sufficient to impact large-scale atmospheric circulation and has devastating impacts on marine ecosystems and resources. The 2010-2011 Ningaloo Niño event was associated with an unseasonable surge of the Leeuwin Current (LC), which transports a large amount of warm waters from the tropics to mid-latitudes. However, dynamical and physical processes that control the LC variability and associated SST changes are not well understood. Also, the relative importance of surface air-sea fluxes and heat advection caused by LC variability for upper ocean warming during Ningaloo Niño events is still unclear.

A primary goal of this project is to understand oceanic and air-sea interaction processes key to the development of the Ningaloo Niño. We have conducted high-resolution ocean general circulation (OGCM) model simulations which can adequately resolve the narrow width of the LC, and analyzed the outputs to investigate the dynamical and physical processes crucial for the Ningaloo Niño development. In particular, the influence of continental shelf-slope on the upper ocean temperature evolution during the Ningaloo Niño is emphasized.

Air-sea fluxes associated with Ningaloo Niño

Ocean circulations play an important role in variability of air-sea fluxes in the southeast Indian Ocean on various time scales. We investigated air-sea flux variability in the southeast Indian Ocean associated with the development and decay of Ningaloo Niño using multiple datasets based on satellite and in-situ observations and reanalysis products.

The composite evolution of air-sea heat fluxes over the life cycle of Ningaloo Niño indicates that the anomalous latent heat flux is dominant for the net surface heat flux variations, and that the uncertainties in latent heat flux anomaly largely depend on the phase of the Ningaloo Niño. During the recovery period of Ningaloo Niño, large negative latent heat flux anomalies (cooling the ocean) are evident in all datasets and thus significantly contribute to the SST cooling. In contrast, the role of latent heat flux during the developing phase is not clear, because the sign of the anomalies depends on the datasets in this period (Fig. 1). The use of high-resolution SST data, which can adequately represent SST variations produced by the anomalous Leeuwin Current, could largely reduce the errors in latent heat flux anomalies during the onset and peak phases (Fig. 2). 

Impact of continental shelf-slope on Leeuwin Current strength and Ningaloo Niño

Previous theoretical studies suggest that the topography along the west coast of Australia plays an important role in strengthening and trapping the Leeuwin Current (LC) at the coast.

To quantify the impact of continental shelf-slope on the LC, we have performed a series of high-resolution OGCM experiments with different bottom topographies. While the OGCM experiment with shelf-slope along the west coast of Australia simulates the realistic LC, the experiment without the shelf-slope generates the LC which is much weaker (~28%) than observations (Fig. 3). These OGCM experiments also demonstrate a substantial influence of the shelf-slope on the upper ocean temperature evolution during the 2010-2011 Ningaloo Niño event through changes of the LC strength (Fig. 4, Fig. 5). The analysis of oceanic processes in these OGCM experiments further indicates that the shelf-slope topography can effectively trap the positive sea level anomaly associated with the LC by suppressing Rossby wave radiation from the coast (Fig. 6).

Intellectual merit

Our numerical model simulations and analyses have identified key physical processes that determine the SST and upper-ocean variability associated with the Ningaloo Niño, which can alter atmospheric circulations. In particular, the impacts of LC dynamics including the effect of continental shelf-slope on the Ningaloo Niño, which cannot be isolated by observations alone, have been quantified by a series of OGCM experiments, and thus our results substantially advanced our understanding of the dynamics of LC system and Ningaloo Niño that is major climate variability in the southeast Indian Ocean.

 Broader impacts

The project has contributed to the plan and design of major international field campaigns and improving observational network in the Indian Ocean, enhancing education through supporting students and a post-doc, and advancing climate prediction. In particular, results from high-resolution modeling were extremely useful for refining planned international field campaigns and for extending the existing observational network. In addition, our institution is recognized as a Hispanic Serving Institution by the U.S. Department of Education, and thus the project contributed to providing training opportunities for underrepresented minorities. Furthermore, the project identified key processes that must be represented well in climate models, which will help improve climate model simulation and benefit society by providing more reliable climate prediction.
